NewsLine.NewsLineText: BUSINESS-HIGHLIGHTS:Reuters Business News Highlights 1125 GMT Sept 23

body.p: Germany faces reform gridlock after election

BERLIN - Germany faced the prospect of continued economic stagnation on Monday after Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder won Sunday's election with a reduced majority that narrowed his scope to implement painful reforms.
Schroeder's centre-left government of Social Democrats and Greens got a majority of just nine over the combined opposition parties, down from 21 at the last election.
War fever drives oil price up to 19-month peak
LONDON - War fever drove U.S. oil prices to a new 19-month high on Monday as dealers took fright at the growing threat of a U.S. assault on Iraq.
Benchmark U.S. crude oil jumped 41 cents to $30.25 a barrel by late morning in London, after setting a high of $30.48, its highest level since February last year.
Beiersdorf shares fly on P&G bid talk
FRANKFURT - Shares in Beiersdorf AG leapt on Monday after a report that U.S. consumer products giant Procter & Gamble was about to bid for Allianz's stake in the maker of Nivea skin products.
Italian jobless rate dips to near 10-yr low

ROME - Italian unemployment slipped in July to its lowest level in almost 10 years, national statistics agency ISTAT said on Monday, providing a rare ray of light for the government in an otherwise murky economic landscape.
The seasonally adjusted jobless rate in the euro zone's third-largest economy was 9.0 percent in July from 9.1 percent in April, ISTAT said in its quarterly unemployment report.
HK deflation spiral persists as Aug CPI dips 3.3 pct

HONG KONG - Consumer prices in Hong Kong fell 3.3 percent year-on-year in August, extending the territory's deflationary trend to a 46th straight month and reflecting stubborn weakness in what was once one of the world's most vibrant economies.
The fall in the composite consumer price index was marginally worse than market forecasts for a 3.2 percent slide.
Qwest to restate $950 mln in capacity sales

DENVER - Qwest Communications International Inc., a local U.S. telephone company facing federal probes of its accounting practices, said on Sunday it expected to restate $950 million in revenues and costs for swaps of optical-network capacity.
The transactions in question include the exchange of optical capacity with other carriers, it said.
R.H.Donnelley buys Sprint phone book for $2.23 bln

NEW YORK - R.H. Donnelley Corp., a yellow page marketing company widely acknowledged to have published the first U.S. telephone directory, returned to its roots on Sunday by agreeing to purchase Sprint Corp.'s phone book business for $2.23 billion in cash.
The transaction will create the largest publicly traded phone book publisher, with more than 260 white and yellow page directories distributed to 18 million customers in 18 states.
Dole CEO makes $1.3 bln offer for rest of company
LOS ANGELES - Dole Food Co. Inc.'s top executive on Sunday offered to buy the remaining shares in the world's largest producer of fresh fruits he does not already own for about $1.26 billion in cash.

David Murdock, Dole's billionaire chairman and chief executive, presented a proposal to the company's board Sunday to purchase the 76 percent stake he and his family do not already own for $29.50 per share, he said in a statement
Taiwan keeps rates steady, but may cut later

TAIPEI - Taiwan's central bank left rates unchanged as expected at its quarterly policy meeting on Monday, as the export-reliant economy warms up during the annual manufacturing peak in the second half.

However, a faltering recovery in the United States -- which absorbs about 30 percent of all Taiwan exports -- could lead the Federal Reserve to trim rates later this year, prompting similar cuts in Taiwan and other Asian peers, said economists.
German vote weighs on stocks, boost bonds

LONDON - Investors dumped stocks and headed for safe haven government bonds on Monday as German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's narrow election victory was seen heralding a period of sluggish growth and delays to reforms in Europe's biggest economy.

Fears of war in the Middle East drove oil prices to year-highs, boosting oil company shares, and propelled gold prices higher in Europe. Currency markets showed little immediate reaction to the German elections.
